Several Members have commented on the need for rational Medisave withdrawal rules to encourage right-siting of patients in the community.  And I agree.  Today, Medisave can be withdrawn for community hospitals, subject to a daily withdrawal limit of $150, up to an annual cap of $3,500. This is largely adequate for patients undergoing rehabilitation.  However, we are stepping up the capabilities of the community hospital so that they can also serve sub-acute patients, for example, those with hip fractures, and elderly with kidney and urinary tract infections.   Traditionally, such patients are kept in acute hospitals where their Medisave withdrawal limits are higher, at $450 per day.  But it makes sense for the patients to be transferred to a community hospital where the total cost is lower.  However, current withdrawal limits may deter such patients from moving to community hospitals because of higher out-of-pocket payments, as Dr Amy Khor pointed out.

 

    To fix this anomaly, we will do two things.  First, we will subvent the community hospitals which partner the acute hospitals to provide sub-acute care, more. The daily norm cost for such cases will increase from $271 to $400 per day.  So this is quite substantial.  Second, we will (a) raise the daily Medisave withdrawal limit for community hospitals from $150 to $250, and (b) raise the annual Medisave withdrawal limit from $3,500 to $5,000.  Together with the enhanced nine-tier subsidy framework for community hospitals implemented last year, these adjustments should make it cheaper for sub-acute patients to move from an acute hospital to a community

Column: 3525

hospital.  I thank Dr Amy Khor for this suggestion.

 

     Medisave can also be used to pay for day rehabilitation services, subject to a daily limit of $20.  We will also be raising this limit from $20 to $25.

 

     We are working with the providers to raise the clinical standard of community-based rehabilitation care. We will involve more skilled therapists in the delivery of care and establish individual care plans and improved outcome monitoring to help ensure patients receive the care they need.  With better treatment, costs will, however, go up and that is why the increase in Medisave withdrawal limit should benefit the patients.

 

     These changes to Medisave withdrawal limits will be implemented in June, in a couple of months' time.

 

     After Government subsidies and Medisave, health insurance in the form of MediShield, ElderShield and their private supplements, form the third layer of protection.  The value of health insurance and the benefits of risk-pooling are well established.  Practically all countries have incorporated insurance into their healthcare systems.  The Germans under Chancellor Bismarck introduced this innovation a century ago.  But we are again unique by insisting on "deductibles and co-payment" in our health insurance framework.  We reject comprehensive health insurance based on "first dollar coverage". Many other countries adopt comprehensive health insurance and are now bogged down by abuses, over-consumption, over-servicing and wastages.  They are all trying to reform their insurance policies, eg, in the US, by introducing "deductibles and co-payment" but find it politically challenging.  Former Health Minister Yeo Cheow Tong incorporated this important feature into

Column: 3526

our health insurance policies and we were wise to have avoided these pitfalls.

 

     Even the Germans who pioneered health insurance are now trying to reform their national health insurance system as abuses are causing massive deficits.  Employers have been shouldering the rising premiums but this has affected their business competitiveness.  They are saying "enough is enough" and are demanding that employees should shoulder future premium increases.  Last week, an article in a German business weekly, Focus Magazine, discussed this issue.  The article was titled "Saving Money With Singapore" and this is an English translation of their German title. I am sure it is more elegant in German.  Its sub-headline read: "The Government is looking at an Asian health regime as a model for the reform of the statutory health insurance system".  The article said that they "are looking into one health system in particular – that of Singapore".  I do not know if our 3Ms is implementable in Germany as our politics are different, but clearly we must be doing something right.

 

     MediShield and ElderShield are not compulsory but, through an opt-out approach, we have achieved good coverage.  MediShield coverage has exceeded 93% for all working adults, and the ElderShield per-cohort coverage is about 90%.  As noted by Dr Lily Neo, there is room for further expansion, but the current picture is not bad.

 

     I have done several enhancements to MediShield and there is scope to do more, for example, to extend it to cover mental illness and congenital illnesses, when the economic condition is conducive.  Mdm Halimah and Ms Denise Phua raised these two ideas several times. I have not forgotten them.

 

     I have also enhanced ElderShield, but I think further enhancement is necessary. 

Column: 3527

ElderShield now pays out $400 per month for up to six years.  This is just about sufficient for the lower-income group who can qualify for heavy subsidy in nursing homes, but it will not be enough for the higher-income group.  They should top up their basic ElderShield with ElderShield supplements.  Some do.  About 14% of ElderShield policyholders subscribe to ElderShield supplements.  It will be a better picture, if another 30% or 40% also join in.

 

     In response to Dr Lily Neo, we are looking to further enhance the basic ElderShield by raising its payout to, say, $800 per month.  But this will require some premium adjustment.  I am trying to see how we can avoid this and I am studying the alternative of maybe bringing forward the entry age from 40 to, say, 35 or 30, which should mean lower premium adjustments.  Effectively, this will allow Singaporeans to spread out their larger premium payments over a longer period of their working life, instead of the current 25 years, in return for higher payouts should they become severely disabled.

 

     The final layer of protection is Medifund.  This is the ultimate safety net to catch anyone who falls through the top three layers.  We have been building it up since its launch in 1993.  With the proposed top up of $200 million, it will reach $2 billion.

 

     Medifund is again unique in Singapore.  We consciously set aside budget surpluses during good time, so that our ability to help the vulnerable during bad times is not diminished by the adverse economic climate.

 

     Last year, when we anticipated more patients asking for financial help, we increased the Medifund disbursement to $75 million.  It was helpful.  While the economy this year should be better, I will nevertheless further raise this year's Medifund budget allocation to institutions

Column: 3528

to $80 million.  This will be funded, as usual, using the interest earned by the endowment fund.

 

     Separately, I have been thinking about how to help lower-income Singaporeans cope with expensive drugs, over and above our current subsidy policy.  Last month, I disbursed an additional $8.5 million to Medifund Committees to enable them to help more patients, especially those requiring HIV medications.  This year, I will inject a further $10 million from Ministry of Health’s operating budget to help deserving patients cope with seven high cost medications used for diseases such as breast cancer, colorectal cancer, ovarian cancer, COPD and asthma.  This should be helpful to many patients suffering from these diseases.  We will leverage on the Medifund mechanism to help disburse this additional financial assistance to deserving patients.  This includes means-testing and some co-payment by patients as the hospitals deem fit.  If the idea proves useful, we can increase the budget allocation to this new Medication Assistance Fund (MAF).

 

      Mr Chairman, our multi-layered protection framework, code-named 3Ms, builds upon and enriches our Government subsidy framework which we inherited from the British. It allows us to combine the best of the British taxation model with the best of the market-based American insurance model.  It is not perfect but it has served us quite well.  I fully agree with Dr Lily Neo that "we need to continually tweak it so as to cater to the growing needs and expectations of our people".   With the support of Members, I will continue to do my best to ensure that all Singaporeans can afford basic healthcare.  This is my pledge.

Banning trans fat

 

     Mrs Mildred Tan (Nominated Member): Sir, many cities such as Boston, New York and Philadelphia have banned trans fat, a food ingredient commonly found in french fries, donuts and other fried foods. Trans fat has been linked to heart disease in humans and diabetes in experimental animals. In Singapore, three in 10 Singaporeans have exceeded WHO's recommended daily limit. Will the Ministry of Health (MOH) consider banning this or increasing public education in the harmful effects of trans fat or consider mandatory labeling; similar to what NTUC FairPrice did with the household products?

 

     Sir, this suggestion is not new.  Back in December 2006, the Health Promotion Board (HPB announced that it would not ban the use of trans fats in food products.  At the time, it gave a long list of reasons mainly based on consumer choice and practical implementations, for example, we consume less fat than Americans. The HPB is hesitant to pass legislation on trans fat as this would result in trade barriers, especially since many food products found here are imported from various countries.  About 70% of packaged food products currently do not carry trans fat labelling and will be affected.  This would limit the choice of food Singaporeans have.  Legislation limiting trans fat to 5% of a product's total fat content would affect 30% of packaged food here.


     Since then, HPB in 2007 announced it would allow food products with little or no trans fat to be labelled accordingly, but it had said "no" to Mdm Halimah Yacob's

Column: 3533

suggestion to move towards compulsory labelling and in the same year, NTUC FairPrice then took up the call to voluntarily declare trans fat content on its household products.  Last year, 2009, in response to Ms Ellen Lee's query on educating the population on the effects of trans fat, the Ministry said that HPB will step up public education on the harms of excessive consumption of trans fat, and work closely with AVA to review trans fat in food supply.

 

     This was in view of the local studies conducted, which showed that 30% of adults here, particularly those aged 18 to 39, exceeded WHO's recommended daily limit.  After three years of deliberation, is it time for us to introduce mandatory or compulsory labelling of trans fat content in food?  At the same time, we should keep in mind the possibility of banning such food in the near future.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Mr Hawazi Daipi):

Column: 3538

Sir, I will try to cover all grounds before the stipulated guillotine time.

 

     I thank Members for speaking on, among other issues, special needs and health promotion.  Speaking of health promotion last month, two UK researchers revealed preliminary findings suggesting that it was possible to be bored to death.  Before Members get worried about their own health since all of us get bored from time to time, let me qualify that statement.  What the study found was that people who regularly feel bored are more prone to becoming unhappy and unmotivated.  This, in turn, can lead them to adopt unhealthy habits, such as smoking, taking drugs or drinking, which increase their chances of dying from conditions such as stroke and heart diseases.

 

     Most Singaporeans I know have the opposite problem – they are so busy they hardly have time to feel bored!  We are a time-starved people.  We work deadlines, manage family commitments, and run countless errands.  Small wonder that we often hear people grumble, "I wish I had more time for the things that matter in life."

 

     Good health is one such thing that matters to all age groups, as Dr Fatimah Lateef has rightly pointed out.  The Ministry of Health (MOH) invests heavily in health promotion precisely because it is the crucial first step to good health.  It is much better to keep healthy rather than seek treatment when conditions develop.  This is why our preventive healthcare budget has increased by 67% over the past decade to $112 million in FY2010.  Our aim is to help Singaporeans of all ages – children, adolescents, adults and the elderly – to have the means and ability to lead healthier lifestyles.  We want to nip chronic health problems in the bud and reduce the disease burden on our ageing population.  I think many Members have alluded to the silver tsunami that is

Column: 3539

coming and asked how we are going to manage it.  It is a tall order which requires hard work from all of us, but it is worth doing.


     Unfortunately, when we need to prioritise our time, a healthy lifestyle is often the first to go.  Many Singaporeans, stressed from work, often do not eat healthily or exercise regularly.  Worse still, they succumb to high-risk habits, such as smoking or heavy drinking, mistakenly viewing all these as a pressure-reliever or a lifestyle choice.  They do not realise or may even ignore the fact that it could cause them greater pressure, both financially and emotionally, when health conditions develop down the road.

 

     This is why there is a strong case for healthy lifestyles to be advocated at the workplace.  The outreach strategy is sound as two out of three Singaporeans aged 15 years and above are working.  I spoke briefly about workplace health in last year’s Budget, and I will spend more time outlining our plans for workplace health promotion this year.

 

     The business case for improving workplace health is simple. Healthier workers mean less absenteeism and lower medical costs for the company.  This is the first step to boosting productivity and the bottomlines.  Healthy, active employees are also good "walking advertisements" for a company’s work ethos and culture, which helps them in talent recruitment and retention. Healthy and alert employees also contribute to a safer work environment.  Indeed, more local companies are recognising the value of good workplace health programmes and have taken steps to implement these.

 

     NatSteel is a good example.  I visited NatSteel last month and was impressed by the fruits of their employees' wellness programme.  They have wisely banned the sale of cigarettes within their premises

Column: 3540

and extended the lunch-time break to encourage participation in on-site health programmes.  I was told by some workers there that they actively take part in the lunch-time programmes to promote good health of their workers.  Employees are also given subsidies and other incentives to participate in healthy lifestyle activities.  There have been tangible results – the average days of medical leave taken has fallen from 3.4 days in 2005 to 2.3 days in 2009.  With more motivated and healthier staff, the monthly average resignation rate has also fallen from 0.9% in 2005 to 0.7% last year.  For comparison, the monthly average for the manufacturing industry is double that, at about 1.6%.

 

     One employee’s effort in keeping himself healthy left a lasting impression on me.  Mr Arumugam Kerisnasamy, a security guard, has a family history of chronic diseases.  Determined to keep these diseases at bay, he put himself through the Health Promotion Board's "Lose to Win Challenge" and NatSteel’s own "Weight Optimisation Challenge" late last year, losing about eight kilogrammes over a four-month period.  Mr Arumugam continues to exercise and watch his diet. He now weighs 96 kilogrammes – about 11 kilogrammes less than when he first started the programme.  His fitness level has also improved considerably.  During my visit, he shared how grateful he was to NatSteel for their support and encouragement in his weight loss journey.  He also told me that he was driven by the strong desire to take charge of his own health so that he can better his work performance and also provide for his loved ones.  I think we all have much to learn from Mr Arumugam.


     Let me talk about support for Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs), something which some Members have spoken on.  Some SMEs may want to roll out similar measures like NatSteel, but

Column: 3541

they lack the scale, resources and infrastructural support to do so.  MOH and HPB recognise the constraints faced by our SMEs and will do more in the coming year to help them.

 

     Today, several industrial and commercial landlords, such as Ascendas Services, CapitaLand Commercial, JTC Corporation, HDB and Mapletree Investments, participate in HPB’s WHP@SMEs’ Doorstep programme.  A simple but popular programme, it conducts health screening and health programmes for SME employees at the doorstep of industrial parks and commercial buildings where the SMEs are located.  This is how HPB brings the programme to the doorstep of the companies.  It has been well received and we intend to roll this out to more locations over time.

 

     I agree with Mr Ong Ah Heng and Mr Yeo Guat Kwang that more can be done.  The National Tripartite Committee on Workplace Health, co-chaired by Mr Lucas Chow and Mr Yeo himself, has recommended to MOH a slew of measures to better support our SMEs in workplace health promotion.  Let me mention a few that we have implemented or are considering in the coming year.

 

     To help SMEs who face budgetary constraints in starting workplace health programmes, the TriComm and HPB have introduced an enhanced SME Grant since May 2009.  The grant now funds up to 90% of the cost of such programmes, capped at $10,000 per application.  HPB also recently relaxed the grant guidelines to allow funding for off-site health programmes, such as basic health screening at CDMP-GP clinics and chronic disease intervention programmes.  HPB has committed up to $180,000 to 22 SMEs under this enhanced scheme.  I encourage more SMEs to sign up for the scheme.

 

Column: 3542

     Money alone cannot fully address the situation.  SMEs often lack dedicated manpower and protected time to implement workplace health programmes well.  To help them, HPB will introduce a workplace health package this month where pre-selected vendors will deliver the packaged health screening and interventions, covering four key areas of healthy lifestyle – physical activity, healthy eating, mental well-being and smoking control.  Companies simply have to choose their preferred activities from among the health interventions in these four areas.

    

     Some Members have raised the concern over mental well-being programmes that can be introduced for employees at company level.  This is one example in which HPB is trying to reach out to employees, to help the workers manage their health issues through activities, including for mental well-being.

 

     We also know that the work demands of each sector are different.  Some sectors, like hospitality, wholesale and retail, and transport and logistics, face greater challenges in implementing workplace health initiatives.  For example, in the hospitality sector, it is hard to get service staff who work different shifts to get together to exercise, especially those who work the night shift. To address this, HPB and its partners will be adopting a more customised approach, by tailoring outreach activities and capacity building sessions tailored for specific industries.  Industry workgroups, comprising representatives from trade associations, unions and private companies, will be set up to provide feedback on the needs and challenges of their respective industries.

 

     Within Government, HPB has already started working with other agencies to align and streamline our promotional efforts.  For example, HPB and the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) have been working closely to integrate workplace

Column: 3543

health promotion into the Workplace Safety and Health legislative framework, as well as the Guidelines for Re-employment of Older Workers.  They will also be engaging employers, employees, healthcare providers and insurers to pilot a health management framework linking corporate and individual health to appropriate incentive systems. This will be an exciting area for development as we push for greater productivity in our workforce.

 

     Sir, I know I can count on our unions and trade associations, like NTUC and the Singapore Manufacturers’ Federation (SMa), to step forward and lend us their support.  NTUC has already partnered HPB to launch a weight management programme next month to promote healthy living at the workplace.  SMa will also hold a kick-off event in May 2010 where some of their SME members will pledge their commitment to implement workplace health programmes.  So we have the unions and employers' association to help us in promoting weight management with their members and employees.  As we intensify our engagement efforts with SME leaders and associations, I hope more will do the same and motivate their members to improve workplace health.


     Let me quickly update Members on smoking control legislation.  Singapore is a pioneer in this area on several counts. We were the first Asian country to ban tobacco advertisements in 1971.  In 2004, we again led Asia by using graphic warnings on cigarette packs to discourage smokers from lighting up.  To date, we are one of the only nine countries in the world recognised by the World Health Organization (WHO) for our nation-wide network of smoking cessation services.

 

     Nevertheless, smoking is an issue that will take years to address and we will persist in it.  We already have some successes.  Less contraband is being

Column: 3544

hawked on the streets, in no small part due to Customs’ vigorous enforcement efforts.  Many public places are also going smoke-free, thanks to the National Environment Agency's smoking ban.  Over the years, smoking rates dropped from 20% in 1980 to 12.6% in 2004, but the latest figure of 13.6% in 2007 shows a slight rebound.  So we still have a lot of work to do.

 

     This is mainly due to an increase in smoking amongst certain population segments, in particular young adults.  The smoking rate for young males, aged 18 to 29 years, has increased from 18% in 2004 to 25% in 2007.  For young females, the increase was from 7% in 2004 to 9% in 2007.  I am concerned about this trend as young adults might not fully appreciate the negative consequences of being hooked on smoking.

 

     Besides stepping up HPB’s public education efforts, we intend to augment the Health Sciences Authority's regulatory arsenal by updating the Smoking (Control of Advertisement and Sale of Tobacco) Act to current operating realities.  The Act was last amended in 2003 and the latest proposed amendments are to incorporate more stringent tobacco control measures in response to an increasing trend of smoking among young adults, and the emergence of new tobacco products.

 

 

After extensive public and industry consultation, we are planning to ban misleading labelling, and lower the maximum tar and nicotine limits, among other changes.  I look forward to Members' support for the amendment Bill when we table it in this House later.

 

2.15 pm

 

     Let me now move to detection and prevention of diseases. Mr Khaw earlier spoke about our considerations in making screening more affordable through the use

Column: 3545

of Medisave.  I shall now update the House on clinical developments.

 

     The Integrated Screening Programme was introduced in June 2008 to facilitate appropriate health screening for Singaporeans aged 40 years and older at CDMP-registered GP clinics.  Five conditions are currently covered – diabetes, high blood pressure, lipid disorders and obesity – all these are risk factors for heart attacks and stroke as well as cervical cancer.  The programme has served Singaporeans well by lowering the cost of screening through bulk purchases and subsidies for lower income Singaporeans. 

 

     We are looking at including colorectal cancer screening under the Integrated Screening Programme.  Colorectal cancer is the most common cancer here – 1,500 Singaporeans become afflicted with this disease annually.  Over the course of a lifetime, one in every 20 men and one in every 30 women will get colorectal cancer. Last November, we started a pilot in Queenstown, Tiong Bahru, Bishan and Ang Mo Kio where Singaporeans aged 50 years and older were invited to go for colorectal cancer screening at CDMP-GP clinics. To-date, 416 participants have completed the screening, and 39 participants, or 9% of them, were referred for further assessment.  We also intend to step up efforts to increase awareness and uptake of colorectal cancer screening among Singaporeans.

 

     Cervical cancer is another noteworthy disease that we are tackling.  Pap smear screening is key to detecting this cancer at its early and even pre-cancerous stages, where treatment is most effective.  Vaccination against the human papillomavirus (HPV) is an interesting new approach, though not without limitations.  For example, it is only effective against 70% of cancer-causing HPV virus, and

Column: 3546

there is limited data on the long-term effectiveness. The Expert Committee on Immunisation is reviewing the evidence on HPV vaccination and will report its finding to MOH subsequently.

 

     Sir, on children's health, I would say that good health boils down to eating enough and eating right. A balanced diet is crucial to improving physical well-being and our resistance against diseases. 

 

     But we must guard against too much of a good thing. Chinese New Year is just over and like during the other festivities like Hari Raya or Deepavali, some of you would have suffered from the side effects of over-eating.  Imagine the ill effects on our our children of over-eating on a daily basis!  Childhood obesity is fast becoming a problem in developed countries.  Left unchecked, it would lead to our children developing all sorts of chronic diseases that they would have to live with the rest of their lives. The problem is becoming so severe in America that it has caught the attention of President Barack Obama.  He recently set up a taskforce under the First Lady to tackle this growing problem. 

 

     In Singapore, we have made obesity the focal point of our National Healthy Lifestyle campaign last year, and this will continue this year. As a lead up to the campaign proper, HPB will launch a weight loss reality TV challenge, similar to the highly popular Lose to Win Challenge in 2009. Community and workplace stakeholders will also be engaged to champion health programmes to provide supportive health promoting environments for optimum weight management.

 

    We know that food advertising to children is a problem, and are working with industry stakeholders to address this. To complement these efforts, HPB is developing guidelines on food marketing to children in schools and will continue health education efforts in the school setting.  HPB will also work with MOE to

Column: 3547

instil a culture of physical activity amongst our young, so as to build lifelong habits for a healthy lifestyle.

 

     Mrs Mildred Tan asked specifically if MOH will consider banning trans fat in food sold here due to the increased risk of coming down with cardiovascular diseases from consuming it.  I share her concern.  Today, three in 10 adult Singaporeans exceed WHO's recommended daily limit of less than two grammes of trans fat a day.  Two-thirds of these people are younger adults aged 18 to 39.  Our children, especially those who snack frequently, are affected as well. We clearly need to limit the intake of trans fat in Singapore before it gains a foothold in our daily life. 

 

    Regulating trans fat, however, is a complex issue.  We have adopted a more cautious voluntary approach so as not to create trade barriers, reduce consumer choice and bring about unintended increases in food prices. The concerns that we raised in 2006, as mentioned by Mrs Tan, are still valid, but we are looking at some ways to ensure that people are better informed about healthy choices.  After carefully studying the experiences of other countries and taking into account our local situation, we are now prepared to take targeted steps to control the problem. 

 

     The experts told me that a total ban is not practical.  Many of the catchy headlines we read about trans fat bans in New York and California actually refer to limiting trans fat to a very low level.  We will do likewise.  We are considering limiting the trans fat content in fats and oils to not more than two grammes of trans fat per 100 grammes of product. This is in line with the practice of developed countries which have implemented trans fat reduction measures. 

 

     For other food products besides fats and oils, HPB will continue its approach of

Column: 3548

engaging the food industry and encouraging all of them to voluntarily reduce the trans fat content in their products. Response has been encouraging, especially from larger players in the market. Some companies have voluntarily reduced trans fat in their products, eg, Gardenia, Sunshine, FairPrice, Lam Soon and Nestle.  SMEs, like Al Dente Food Pte Ltd, have also come forward to partner us in this effort. I look forward to the support of other industry players on this and other healthy eating initiatives like HPB's Healthier Choice certification.

 

     Mr Low Thia Khiang asked about the state of myopia in Singapore. Myopia develops mainly in childhood, but stabilises as we get older.  Many of us will recall that one generation ago, fewer children wore spectacles. The proportion of school children in Singapore with myopia is indeed high but has also stabilised over the past five years. Today, about 30% of Primary One school children and two-thirds, or 66%, of Primary Six children have myopia. 

 

     The causes of myopia are not well-defined, although studies have identified risk factors like near work mentioned by Mr Low, and protective factors like regular outdoor activity.  Local research is ongoing to gain more insights into risk factors and causes of myopia.  Our schools have taken the necessary measures to manage the problem but a large part of the solution depends on habits at home. Through the National Myopia Prevention Programme, MOH and HPB help tackle both sides of the equation by educating parents, educators and children themselves on good eye care.  Vision screening for pre-school to secondary school students is also provided through the Programme. We must collectively press on our efforts to delay the onset and reduce the progression of myopia in children on these fronts.  But we acknowledge that it is challenging.

 

Column: 3549

     As these recent cohorts of children age, myopia will inevitably become more prevalent among adults. The concern is that myopia may predispose older adults to other eye problems.  HPB will encourage seniors to go for vision screening as part of a broader suite of elderly functional assessments which it will roll out soon.  They are also augmenting optometry and optician services nationwide to deal with problems as they emerge. 

 

     Fortunately, myopia is a problem easily correctable by spectacles or contact lenses.  With affluence, many adults have also gone for the more costly option of laser surgery or LASIK.  The technology is evolving. Surgeons are now able to make more precise, three-dimensional measurements of the eye that better guide the reshaping of the cornea. However, as with any surgical procedure, patients have to be carefully assessed for suitability, and LASIK itself carries risk that patients should be aware of. At our public hospitals, the success rate of improving vision in adults via LASIK is more than 98%, though not all will achieve perfect vision.  This is comparable to results overseas.  Rates of serious complications are low, but side effects such as dry eyes are common, occurring in up to half of all patients. 

 

     Let me now talk about special needs children.  Besides mainstream school children, I want to highlight another group that we are devoting more resources to – the special needs children. Dr Lam Pin Min and Dr Amy Khor have raised some good questions about our plans to support this group of children. Since 1991, the Child Development Programme has helped identify and treat children with developmental problems in their early childhood. Under this programme, child development experts from KKH, NUH and three community-based clinics work together to provide diagnostic and early

Column: 3550

intervention services for special needs children aged 0 to 6, complementing MCYS and MOE's efforts under the wider Enabling Masterplan on Disability. Through these efforts, and the determination of patients and their families, many have risen above their developmental difficulties.  Some ex-patients have since secured places in our tertiary institutions and even participated actively in National Service. 

 

     I have seen our healthcare professionals in action. They are doing good work and coping relatively well despite the huge caseload of some 5,200 patients, including 2,000 new cases annually.  However, certain support services, like psychological counselling and speech therapy, are stretched as we have only catered for a projected total caseload of 3,200, with 1,200 or so new cases per year.  This was the global norm as recently as three years ago. 

 

     This rising trend in workload, which experts attribute to increased awareness and better diagnostics, is not unique to Singapore. The situation is exacerbated by a global shortage of trained manpower, which had led to a resultant increase in waiting times worldwide. We acknowledge that parents have to wait before sending their children for screening, but we are managing this by trying to increase the manpower.  But I would like to inform Members that this is not just a problem in Singapore but it is also faced by many countries in other parts of the world.  This is why we are injecting $46 million into the Child Development Programme, to help us expand capacity and bring down waiting times for these early childhood developmental services.  It will cover our needs over the next four years and it is on top of the $16 million already committed from 2007 to 2009.  Most of these monies will go towards the training and recruitment of child development manpower, especially psychologists and speech language and physiotherapists.  At steady state, we hope to

Column: 3551

serve more than 6,000 cases yearly and further bring down waiting time for key services. 

 

     But let me add that the holistic management of children with special needs is a very complex issue.  Multi-agency efforts across the social, educational  and healthcare sectors are required for the child to reach his or her full potential, as I am sure Mr Ong Ah Heng is aware.  In the majority of children with special needs, such as those with severe mental retardation, autism and cerebral palsy, medical intervention plays only a limited and supportive role compared to the provision of social and educational support measures.

 

 

These children require early placement in special schools where they can receive appropriate training and education.  The child development programme which I have just outlined caters to those with mild to moderate problems.  The most appropriate developmental setting for this group is in the mainstream – integrated and inclusive schools where they can receive educational, social and community support as well as therapeutic intervention from healthcare professionals.

 

2.30 pm

Prof. Paulin Straughan's questions on raising the quality and standard of traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) in Singapore.  Today, MOH does this through raising the standards of TCM training courses and continuing professional education of TCM practitioners.  Since 2006, MOH has worked with two main local TCM colleges to replace certificates and diploma courses with higher requirement Bachelor courses, jointly conducted with top TCM universities in China.  NTU's School of Biological Sciences has also started a double degree biomedical science and Chinese medicine course with the Beijing University of Chinese medicine.  Its first

Education policy for the 21st century

 

     Mrs Josephine Teo (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Mr Chairman, Sir, I beg to move,

 

     That the total sum to be allocated for Head K of the Estimates be reduced by $100.

 

     Sir, our education system has worked well and we have much to be thankful for.  Therefore, it is natural to prefer

Column: 3615

incremental changes that do not rock the boat too much.  We should affirm the efforts of the MOE which has, over the years, taken bold actions to update our education system to keep it current, even if they unsettle parents and students.  Though we have made continuous improvements, I wonder if the change from within is happening as quickly as the change from without.  Consider the fact that today's 5-year old pre-schooler will likely remain in the workforce till the year 2070, perhaps even later.

5.05 pm

 

     Remember that five years ago, when the pre-schooler was born, the iPhone did not exist and yet, over Chinese New Year, more than half the people I met owned one.  The computer in our mobile phones today is a million times cheaper, a thousand times more powerful and about a hundred thousand times smaller than a computer in 1965, the year Singapore achieved independence.  We can hardly imagine what the world will look like in five years, much less 60.  The US Department of Statistics estimated that the average learner today will have 10 to 14 jobs by the time they are 38.   The top 10 in-demand jobs today did not exist in 2004.  Many of today's University courses did not exist 10 years ago, eg, Nanotechnology, New Media, E-business and Renewable Energy.  What will our students study in 10 years?  How will teachers cope with the generation of totally wired teens? 

 

     Our education system is being depended upon to prepare young Singaporeans for jobs and technologies that do not yet exist, to solve problems we cannot yet identify, for a lifespan that may be much longer than we can imagine.  Given such a backdrop, what kinds of change are needed to be meaningful and

Column: 3616

useful?  First, we need to consider new meanings of literacy.  We typically define a literate as a person who can read and write.  But in the increasingly connected world where information availability is growing at exponential rates, reading and writing are grossly insufficient.  Literacy should be expanded to include the skill of understanding complexity and related to the skill of understanding complexity are multi-cultural sensitivity, context-setting and decision-making skills.  Without these new skills, a person may well be handicapped in the new world.


     Take for example, multi-cultural sensitivity.  Today, how confident are we that young Singaporeans have a pan-Asian outlook?  Can they name the capitals of 10 Asian countries?  Can they say something meaningful and interesting about the different Asian cultures?  Have they visited some of our closest neighbours in ASEAN and made friends there?  And yet if they do not, how do they help the businesses based in Singapore, whether MNCs or GLCs, navigate these complex environments and achieve their pan-Asian ambitions?  How possible is it for us to become a Global-Asia hub, a strategy proposed by the ESC, if we do not cultivate multi-cultural literacy in our young?


     Singapore should take the lead to expand educators' understanding of literacy and build new skills in our students.  We are well placed to do so and, in the process, can create new advantages for our young in a globalised world, much like the way we have created an advantage through bilingualism.  Do not get me wrong.  The traditional 3Rs – Reading, Writing and Arithmetic, are still needed.  But new competencies for our young are needed for the 21st century.  This is because education in the 21st century will not just involve finding the right answers, but asking the right questions.  An educated person will no longer be content with knowing the

Column: 3617

"what" and "how", but instead, wants to be convicted about the "why".  Education, properly carried out, will not only enable a person to fulfil his potential, but to discover his passion and purpose, and to live his life with everyday greatness.  


     I have previously written about the new 3Rs – Roundedness, Rootedness and Resilience.  New 21st century competencies such as critical inquiry and inventive thinking can and should be developed for a more rounded education.  How should the curriculum be updated to reflect these new needs and to benefit all students?  Besides academic achievement, we also need to put more emphasis on whole-person development, in other words, holistic education.  The teaching of PE and Art, for example, has much room for improvement.  To be sure, whenever we visit schools, there are always showcases of sporting or artistic talents.  But, "one swallow does not a summer make", so I often wonder if we are just being shown the isolated achievements of a few.


     At present, curriculum time for PE and Art is very limited.  PE time for Primary 1 and  Primary 2 is only one hour a week whereas from Primary 3 onwards, it is one and a half hours.  In secondary school, it is back to one hour a week.  Also, it has become common place for sport-CCA groups to take in only pupils who have the potential to compete and win medals for the school.  This elite mindset is a great pity because sports should be for everyone.  Through sports, we learn how to collaborate with one another, to have a winner's spirit and to take failure in our stride.  We have no one else to blame for our "strawberry" generation if we do not develop resilience in our young through the rough and tumble of sports.  I would like to know what steps MOE will take to

Column: 3618

promote more inclusive enrolment in sports-CCAs?

     Besides curriculum time, we also need to strengthen the teaching staff and recognise their professionalism.  There is a shortage of teachers trained to teach Art.  Often, Art teachers have to double-up and teach other subjects.   It would be better to have subject specialists for Art, just as we do for Mathematics, Science and English, to encourage professionalism.  MOE should also set targets for each school to have minimum staffing of Art specialists.


     Madam, I believe increased curriculum time and teacher development are still insufficient.  I would like to encourage MOE to send a strong signal to parents and students by introducing three new categories in the Edusave Merit Bursary Awards for achievements in Sports, Art and Music.   I suggest that MOE studies the feasibility in the next few months, establish the criteria and target to recognise 1,000 of such non-academic achievers each year beginning in school year 2011. 


     In conclusion, Madam, it is said that there are only two lasting bequests we can give to our children.  One is roots and the other is wings.  While we are busy fitting our children out with new and better wings through 21st century competencies and a more rounded education, we must not forget to help them develop their moral compass and their national identity.  In times of uncertainty and crises, rootedness and resilience are what will carry us through.  In pursuing holistic education in the 21st century, the roles of teachers will shift.  From their primary role as a dispenser of information, teachers are more likely to become conductors of learning symphonies, helping students turn information into knowledge, knowledge into wisdom, and wisdom into contributions for a better world.


    

Column: 3619

Schools too will be changed, from "buildings" to "nerve centres", connecting teachers, students and the community to the wealth of knowledge that exists in the world.  All of these will have an impact on the way we spend each dollar set aside for education.  What new investments are needed?  Should we continue to think in terms of funding for the primary, secondary, tertiary levels?  Or is it more meaningful for us to think in terms of budgets for outcomes like Basic Literacy, 21st Century Competencies, Character Development?  How should the Ministry's KPIs be adjusted?

 

     Madam, education is a constant work in progress but because we already have a well-functioning system, the possibilities for greater heights of achievements are endless.  However, as Albert Einstein cautioned, "We cannot solve problems using the same kind of thinking we had when we first created them."   We need new thinking and courage to make bold changes.  It is a transformation that should engage all the stakeholders in Singapore.  These include our parents and employers, our educators, our lawmakers, community leaders, and most of all our students.


     I hope the MOE will engage all of these stakeholders actively in the Debate about the future of education in Singapore.

 

All-round education

Column: 3620

ability to listen, empathy, the ability to build rapport, being able to communicate, the ability to resolve conflicts and having a sense of humour – enable human beings to communicate, relate and interact with one another. With good social skills, understanding and development of common goals would be made much easier.

 

 

5.15 pm

 

     As MOE recognises that social emotional learning enables students to develop skills to succeed in life, I would like to ask about the progress our schools are making in developing social skills in our young.  One core competency which I believe our students should possess is public speaking and presentation. Surely, the ability to speak publicly and present clearly, confidently and coherently counts as an important social skill in the productivity-driven culture of the new decade.  In any organisation, the ability to speak and present is a vital and much-valued skill. 

 

     Many of us are impressed, from time to time, with the powerful presentation skills of Americans who are able to speak comfortably to an audience.  There are those who will say that it is all air, that the ability to talk, speak or chat constitutes more form than substance.  However, I would say that since we, Singaporeans, already have a fair amount of substance, and if we work on improving and honing our form, we would be able to take on the world.  Let us do away with the "we are doers, not talkers" mentality and adopt the "can do, can talk" mentality.

 

     I urge MOE to develop a comprehensive programme to uplift the speaking and presentation skills of our students so that they are able to verbalise and communicate ideas effectively.  I observe that our present system tends to favour and nurture those who are already gifted speakers.  In schools, we have the high achievers with their oratory talents who

Column: 3621

do Singapore proud by winning debating awards in the international arena.  Then there are also those who are already competent speakers who will either readily volunteer or be chosen by their teachers as safe bets or deserving for activities which require good speaking skills, such as acting as master of ceremonies at school functions.

 

     But what about the remaining students who form the vast majority?  At school functions and debates, they just sit back and watch their eloquent schoolmates on stage, aware that their own development in public speaking and presentation is limited to a random chance to make presentations in the odd school project or only during special one-off public speaking courses at school.  We should aim at raising the frequency and standards of formal oral communication at every level and there is no better place to do so than the school environment.  We should develop our students early from primary school, starting with show and tell sessions and speech and drama lessons, so that they gradually build the confidence to speak and present persuasively as they move up the learning ladder.  Programmes with the long-term objective of enabling all students to achieve their full potential in speech and presentation should be carried out consistently and progressively throughout the primary, secondary and post-secondary school years.  Such programmes can weave opportunities to develop public speaking and presentation skills into the curriculum across subjects and levels.  By the time the student leaves school, he or she should be able to speak confidently in any situation, convey ideas articulately and deliver polished presentations to any group of people.

 

     Madam, I would like now to touch on the subjects of PE, music and art.  When asked what their favourite subject is,

Column: 3622

many a young school-goer will gleefully reply "recess!"  Not surprisingly, PE, music and art rank as the favourite subjects for many of our little ones once they are told that recess, fun as it is, is not a subject. 

 

     What are the key performance indicators of PE, music and art programmes respectively?  For example, will every child be physically fit, be motivated to keep fit and have been introduced to a variety of sports and physical activities by the time he leaves school?  Will every child be able to play a musical instrument or appreciate a classical music performance by the time he or she leaves school?  Will every child be able to appreciate different media and techniques, the relationship between the visual arts and other disciplines and appreciate visual art in relation to history and different cultures long after he folds away his last school uniform?

 

     PE, art and music, being non-core and non-academic subjects, tend to get sidelined by other subjects, like mathematics and science.  In schools, the temptation to use art, music and PE periods for other subjects, especially around examination time, is strong.

 

    If we are serious about providing our children with quality PE, music and art education, we should have teachers who have in-depth knowledge and are specially trained to teach in these areas. Precious time is wasted and interest lost if children do not receive instructions from specialists in these areas who can give a better insight into their area of specialty and are more likely to infect and inspire the children with their enthusiasm.

 

    For instance, in one art lesson, primary school students can be instructed simply to paint a scene in a park and be allowed to proceed as they please or, alternatively, they can be shown a few different techniques and styles that have been used by artists over the ages before being asked to paint a scene in the park in a

Column: 3623

style they prefer.  In the former scenario, they are allowed to express themselves creatively while in the latter scenario, they are not only able to express themselves but they also learn appreciation of the work of other artists and take with them some understanding of art in a historical context.

Moral and political education

 

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines): Madam, our young today are bombarded with all sorts of ideas through the Internet.  Actions that once scarcely entered the realm of fantasy are now presented on the Internet not only as entertainment, but as reality.  The blog post claiming that Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew had suffered a serious heart attack is a case in point.  It said Singapore would face "total destruction" due to a

Column: 3624

"power vacuum".  The post was a hoax but spread like wildfire through the Internet.  One can sit back and say – well, freedom of speech.  But does this entail the freedom to spread such lies and bring harm to the country?

 

     It is such questions that our young should learn to grapple with.   Given this new reality, our students need to be equipped with the reasoning skills and moral values to face the challenges of living in the 21st century.  They need to learn how to think through the arguments and evidence, come to their own rational conclusions and to work out right from wrong.  To do this, we should review the education curriculum and build in the teaching of moral values and political awareness with an emphasis on the exercise of reason. 

 

     A good way to approach this is through the subjects of history and literature.  Where we can, we should draw from local sources and examples, so that the students can see the direct relevance to their lives.  The goal is not to indoctrinate, but to encourage individuals to face the contradictions and dilemmas faced in any course of action and to provide them the opportunity to arrive at fair solutions.  At the same time, we should imbue in our students a strong sense of national identity.

 

     More should be done to insert key narratives about our founding leaders and pioneers into our history books.  Kishore Mahbubani, the Dean of the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy, rightly noted in the Straits Times last week that strong nations are built on inspiring narratives about their past.  He called it a great tragedy that few students knew of their founding fathers.  This ignorance extends to our early pioneers.  A student wrote in my Facebook that it is strange how our students could reel off the names of figures from China’s imperial history, but

Column: 3625

"they are not able to tell who is Aljunied, Eunos or Nee Soon!" 

 

     At the same time, we should teach our students that history emerges from the examination of evidence and the exercise of reason.  For example, there has been some discussion recently about what would Singapore be like if the Barisan Sosialis had won in 1963, and not the PAP.  Will it lead to a peaceful socialist paradise, as some today seem to think?  Or to a troubled pro-China Communist state, as others do.  Or is this only so much navel-gazing?

 

     I believe that such discussions are not without merit.  But to do this intelligently, one needs to understand the regional and global events at the time, and the political forces at play.  One also must also learn to appraise claims and counterclaims, separate supportable assertions from fabrications, scrutinise the evidence, detect flaws in arguments and reject unjustified inferences and generalisations.

 

     For example, Australia’s then Prime Minister and Minister for External Affairs, Robert Menzies, stated in a Cabinet note in 1961, that if Singapore were to win independence on its own without merger, Singapore would be easily subverted by Communist China.  "It would in time almost certainly be governed by radical Chinese aiming at close association with Communist China."

 

     Whereas, today, some former Barisan leaders who in the 1960s opposed merger, now say that had the Barisan come into power, there would have been more welfare for the people, and so on. No mention about the Communist danger.

 

     Madam, to analyse the lessons of history, we must know our history and learn how to evaluate the evidence.  To ask students to be educated on our

Column: 3626

political history is not the same thing as politicising our education system.  As Aristotle said, "politics is the 'master science' among men."

 

The future and relevance of education

 

     Miss Penny Low: Madam, when our children have a question, who do they call?  Parents – maybe; teachers – maybe; peers – maybe.  Wikipedia and Google - probably!

 

     The infinite information access at real time means that the highest utility children get out of education today is no longer just pure knowledge, nor skills that revolve around recall and process. Our external online brain does that nicely. What it does not do is to give meaning to knowledge, adapt to fast changing external environment, make sound and wise judgment, so we can combine knowledge with humanity to solve problems.  Question:  how can schools stay relevant, impart agility, wisdom and value systems that are apt for the 21st century global citizens? 

 

     Madam, studies have pointed to the emergence of a new human species, called the "homo zappiens" (Gen Z). These are children born into multi-channel, globally connected vatar world, where they are bombarded with a kaleidoscope of multi-channel media from birth.  As a result, their brains are wired differently from the homo sapiens to help them learn in a non-linear and visual manner, such that they can genuinely multi-task like an octopus.  If this is true, it has huge implications.  For one, the connected cyber and real world would truly become the homo zappiens’ oyster.

 

     Next, the simple act of multi-player computer games, combined with simultaneous multi-party online chats and calls, can very quickly become platforms for collaborative and creative problem solving.  Cyber tracks will blossom in this global

Column: 3627

playground giving new meanings to relationships, transform the human web as well as reorganise the way we work, live and play.  Harnessed properly, such platforms can also promote mutual understanding and cultural melting pots, thereby averting potential conflicts and clashes.  But, of course, the reverse is also true.

 

     As our information environment is finally catching up to human capabilities, we are now beginning to see learning environments created to capitalise on our natural and intuitive inclinations – which are all around curiosity, interest-oriented skill acquisition, and project-based implementation.  Music, art, sports and common interest that transcends language barriers and promotes creativity will become the new common language and academic driver.

 

     In the US, experiments are being done using mobile technology to deliver education.  For example, a fifth grade mobile phone learning programme that incorporates the game theory was rolled out as an experiment that has got rather complex information gathering and decision making processes in the game. The findings are summarised by the designer Katie Salen, and I quote: 

 

     "Games are exceptionally good at engaging kids … They drop kids into complex problems where they fail and fail, but they try again and again."

 

In short, such mobile or video games have outperformed teachers

 

 

in one key way and that is they command attention for hours and cultivate a new breed of children who are potentially less risk averse and better at absorbing information coming from all directions.

 

5.30 pm

 

     Going forward, the way we design our curriculum will shape not just the

Column: 3628

organisational gestalts of our children's thought processes but more deeply how they interact with everyone on planet earth to a greater degree than ever before.  We are entering a completely new form of society that offers new opportunities to revolutionise teaching roles,  content and learning methods that enables our citizens to navigate the highly connected knowledge intensive world.  Schools, therefore, will have to seriously rethink their educational value, redesign the educational framework and rebuild the methodologies that will work for this 21st century homo sapiens.

 

     But, Madam, on my wish list is that schools will also seriously embed the humanity quotient into education alongside with aspects of culture and history and this I echo my colleagues Ms Irene Ng, Mrs Josephine Teo and Mr Ong Kian Min so that the homo sapiens will not become a disconnected breed that loses the soul of humanity while the world becomes its oyster.

 

Value of learning vs. quantity learnt

 

     Ms Joscelin Yeo (Nominated Member): Madam, Deputy Prime Minister Teo mentioned briefly the other day that his new Council would be seeking to instil a lifelong learning culture in adult Singaporeans.  I would like to propose that this same culture be instilled in our young as well.  Deputy Prime Minister Teo defined productivity as a measure of how much output we can get from our input.  However, in relation to our young people, I view productivity as them learning a subject matter that will equip them to be effective and excellent at what they do in the future, lending value to our society.

 

     Madam, the amount of information that a youth must learn today has significantly increased in both quantity and complexity from the time that we, those sitting here, were in school.  Yet, if this has not made any of us less capable, why should we attempt to cram

Column: 3629

so much more information into them this day and age?  I am aware that society and standards have changed with time but the reason our Government is as effective as it is today is not because we had a mountain of information poured into us but rather all of us here have learnt and grown better through time, opportunity and desire.  It is this same desire that we must create in our youths today.

The value imparted during the process of learning is more valuable to them in the long run than piling on information and more work as the quest for greater knowledge and, therefore, increase productivity.   When they catch this love for learning, we will have a new generation that is hungry to grow and excel in whatever area of work they set their mind to.  This translates into increased productivity in many sectors of our economy in the future.

 

Column: 3630

     I was excited to read in the Straits Times last week that Crescent Girls' School has developed interactive materials that incorporate multimedia features to pique their students' interest in learning.  Quoting a Secondary 1 student from the article, she said, "When I read normal textbooks, my eyelids will just droop and I cannot continue reading but with the digital textbooks there are so much colour and action, especially in the videos. To raise the productivity of our students, it is not to increase their workload but rather to get more innovative in the way we educate our young and they will, in turn, enjoy the work, achieve mastery over these subjects and, along the way, catch this culture of lifelong learning.

Letting teachers teach

 

     Mr Viswa Sadasivan (Nominated Member): The "Goh Report" of 1979, authored by a team led by the then Minister for Education, Dr Goh Keng Swee, heralded the introduction of the New Education System which has been the basis of our education till today.  The expressed purpose was to "eliminate wastage" in education and increase employability.  Indeed, the education system achieved both, and today has earned respect especially for its systematic approach and rigour in delivering results.

 

     The New Education System has served us well thus far, but it is increasingly evident that it may not be enough in preparing us for the present and especially future challenges, where what is certain is uncertainty.  We need a new breed of people, especially young people, with abilities to cope with adversity and to succeed, not just technical skills.  Definitely, if we want to boost productivity and have greater

Column: 3632

innovation – we need to produce more lateral thinkers, problem solvers and, very importantly, a lot more people who take pride in what they do and think beyond just themselves.

 

     The key desired outcome of education today, therefore, would be to inspire a confident, self assured and driven young population, with skills to analyse, the propensity to come up with out-of-the-box solutions, and that is socially conscious.  This spells character and attitude.  Teachers are an intrinsic and vital factor in this equation.  They need to have the time, indeed, the emotional bandwidth to imbibe this in our youth.  Each one of us here can attest to one or two teachers who have made that impact in our lives.  I remember my Primary 2 teacher, Mr Tang, who, through our many conversations made me realise that if there is something important enough to me I should just do it and not wait for someone else to do it.  This has had a lasting impression on me.  Yes, I was fortunate to have a teacher like Mr Tang.  But today, I am not sure if the same Mr Tang would have the time, the energy to do the same thing – given the pace of life and the workload that teachers have. 


     Over the years, the Ministry of Education has introduced measures to free-up time for teachers to interact with students.  The "Teach Less, Learn More" initiatives, the adjunct teacher and teaching aid schemes and having retired senior officers from the SAF to become operational managers and VPs in schools are examples.  Yet, I am still meeting teachers who seem frustrated by the amount of administrative and other non-core duties that leave them with too little time and energy, let alone to interact with students to teach them.

 

     The non-core activities cited by teachers include NE lessons and activities, planning and organising special activities and events such as school visits by VIPs,

Column: 3633

Speech Day, career festivals, entrepreneurship workshops and formalised community engagement activities.  In addition, some teachers tell me they are also roped in for marketing and PR initiatives in the school.  While they acknowledge the need for these activities and the importance, they seem frustrated by the opportunity cost, which is less quality time with the students.  In fact, even some school principals, I get the sense, would prefer more time to focus on improving the teaching and character building aspects instead of the administrative aspects of their jobs.

 

     To give principals and teachers even more time to focus on teaching and character building, I have a few suggestions:


     Engage a professional CEO for each school – we now have a strong pool of retired corporate CEOs and others with credible management experience and network that would prove invaluable in the administrative, financial, business development, marketing, PR and fund raising aspects of running schools.  There could be two leaders in each school – the CEO, who would be the administrative head, and the Head Master or Mistress who has the final say on all academic and pedagogical matters.  This is a system that is similar to that practice in many hospitals where the CEO is a non-medical professional who, on medical issues, takes the cue from the Chairman, Medical Board – a seasoned medical practitioner.  From what I understand, the system has worked well in hospitals.  By engaging experienced, retired personnel to be CEOs and possibly hold other positions in schools – not only do you allow teachers more time to teach as non-core tasks are taken off their plate, you also give experienced retirees another meaningful way of contributing.  Of course, there are principals today who have strong

Column: 3634

    I am sure Members were shocked as I was when they heard Ms Mildred Tan speak of an example.  Shocking – in Singapore!  We will have to say that the facts are not verified.  We are verifying the facts but it is believable that there are young children – I do not know whether there are adolescents – who become pregnant.  It brings to home how schools are fundamental learning ground and how we need to work with society to help our children navigate moral values, confidence, etc, in various aspects.  For that particular case, we will look up the facts and work with MCYS and our schools and we will report back to Parliament because I think it is an important enough case for us to address adequately, but I do not have facts here and I will reply to Parliament when we do.

 

    Let me thank Members for their overwhelming support.  I have not heard anyone say that we are spending too much. I thank them for their overwhelming support for our large investments in education and their support affirms that, by and large, we

Column: 3655

spend our education dollars well.  There are many suggestions about what our education system should be but I think generally most of us agree that our students across the spectrum of academic ability receivea first-class education and at all levels – whether it is primary, secondary and post-secondary institutions, ITE, Polytechnics and Universities. The system we have today is a far cry from what we have inherited when we became independent.  In the first PSLE held in 1960, we have it in our records, guess what the passing rate was – 55% failed!  If you were the Permanent Secretary and the Minister, well, you can only go up from there – 55% failed, try to do better.

 

     Since then, we have persisted in our efforts to upgrade educational opportunities for all – steadily focusing on the fundamentals to build a cadre of good school teachers and leaders, to develop a rigorous curriculum and then to ensure that our assessment systems are of high quality and valued by educational institutions and employers worldwide.

 

     Outsiders have noted our achievements too. Let me share one anecdote. Last year,Cambridge University ’s Vice-Chancellor Prof. Alison Richard, who was here to address the Cambridge alumni, said that Singapore was "renowned for its long-term investment in science and technology, for its commitment to nurturing exceptional talent, and also for encouraging students to study abroad – well before it became fashionable". And indeed she is right, we do not do things because it is fashionable. We continue to focus on the basics. She went on to relate that a hundred years ago, the Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate was in Singapore administering school examinations and setting educational standards. But, today, Singapore is considered a leader in educational innovations and a key partner for its international division - it is now renamed Cambridge International

Column: 3656

Examinations (CIE).  So the Cambridge certificate that you have, the organisation has been renamed, it is called CIE.  CIE staff conduct examinations for many countries outside the UK. When they talk to these countries about their school curriculum, they tell us that these countries say to them "we want to be like Singapore". We regularly receive many delegations from overseas, including Ministers of other top-performing systems, who visit our schools and institutions and they are impressed. They visit our schools. We do not suggest to them which school.  We say, "Well, this is a panel, you decide which one."  Mrs Josephine Teo made a point that when she goes to school, she sees art being conducted and sometimes she is not sure whether that swallow makes the summer.  I invite Members to choose any school they like because it is system-wide, we let them look at our schools and they feedback to us that they  are impressed with the level of engaged learning in our classrooms.

 

     But we are careful not to let these praises get to our head. In fact, often we say, "Look at our system, we do not want to teach anyone, we do not think we are in a position to but if you can learn something from the system, you tell us what you need to know."  The positive comments encourage us to continually seek for ways to improve. We engage and listen to MPs in this House as well as to the broad segments of society for their views on education as an ongoing exercise, and we view education reform as a continuous journey because we have to equip each generation of Singaporeans adequately for their future.

 

     Mrs Josephine Teo made that stark remark that Primary 1 students today will still be in the workforce in 2070, for the future that we cannot know or challenges that we cannot predict.  She is right.  So the Government is committed to continue this major focus on education and we do

Column: 3657

this not only because it is critical for our economic competitiveness but for Singaporeans, it enables them to move up.  As Dr Lily Neo and Ms Indranee Rajah noted in the Budget debate, for low-income families, it provides the uplifting power to break the poverty cycle.

 

     This is why in last year’s Budget – not too distant away, let me remind Members – in the immediate aftermath of the global financial crisis,  we continued to increase our spending on MOE. The financial crisis was worse end of the year, Budget was brought forward because we wanted to have a response, and even then we increased – by the good grace of MOF – our spending and our budget was  $8.7 billion in FY09, an increase of 5.5% from FY08. And this year’s education budget is a further increase from last year’s – an 11% increase, to $9.7 billion. While we appreciate the overwhelming support of Members for our spending on education, MOE will still ensure that spending is prudent, in order to maintain the strong support that we have from Members.

 

     Mrs Josephine Teo asked a very critical question – how does MOE approach its funding, where do you put your priorities, where do you put your dollars, and what do you hope to achieve.  I will provide sectoral and numerical details later.  But let me first say that the broad approach over the last two decades – if you look at the various initiatives across different Ministries, across different top management – has been consistent and there are two key aspects. First, it is to expand opportunities in education for all through building a mountain range of educational programmes with more peaks of excellence; second, to rebalance our system towards building values and skills to achieve broader educational outcomes. Just focus mainly on these two broad aspects – a mountain range of peaks and rebalancing

Column: 3658

towards values and skills, much of which many Members in their speeches before me focused upon. So it affirms to us that MOE is moving in the right direction. 

 

     In fact, within the last decade or so, we have gone a considerable distance to cater to the diverse spectrum of abilities in all our students. In particular, we want to create paths for those with different learning styles.  Members talk about late bloomers and let me provide some details of our various initiatives.

 

    Across schools, Normal stream students have benefited from more flexibility in streaming. Last year, 4,750 Normal stream students benefited from taking a higher level subject. In fact, last year about one in three Normal (Academic) students took an O-level subject, and majority did well. Normal (Academic) and Normal (Technical) students can also take modules which are delivered in collaboration with Polytechnics and the ITE and these provide them with course credits which they can use when they subsequently study there.

 

     The Direct School Admission (DSA) framework has also widened the scope for students to be selected into secondary schools and post-secondary institutions. Ms Denise Phua said she was shocked – 177 advertisements on tuition. It is a competitive system. But what we have done is to also recognise other talents. We cannot stop parents from wanting their children to do better than the others. But what we can do is to recognise their abilities. For instance, in some of our IP schools today, one in two, 50% of students, enters through the Direct School Admission.  Let me give one example to bring this point home.  Like Elaine Ng, she missed the PSLE cut-off for Nanyang Girls' High but entered through DSA because she was a talented in Chinese dance; she is Chinese. So far, she has done her school proud in winning gold with honours at last year’s Singapore

Column: 3659

Youth Festival, and she is now part of the school’s Mathematics and Science talent programme. So through the DSA, we are able to recognise wider domains of talent.

 

     But beyond these systemic measures, as Members have emphasised, schools are ultimately the nurturing ground for all our educational endeavours, and I take Ms Denise Phua’s rich suggestions. We will study them because each one does require a lot of study, but I take the point that at the ground it is the schools that impact the students positively.  And to maximise our reach, this is the reason why we provide extra resources for all principals to tap on, to fund deserving programmes. Let me give you a feel. For each school, we give Opportunity Funds, Edusave grants and Internationalisation Funds. So just these three big ticket items.  Taken together, this means that a typical primary school has on average an additional $170,000 per annum that they can draw and tap on or apply for.  A secondary school has an additional $300,000, and they use this to provide enrichment opportunities for all students. On top of this, primary and secondary schools can also apply for funding of up to $50,000 per year if they want to develop niche programmes in various fields.  We do not prescribe it, they just have to justify that there is an educational component and merit to it.

 

     This approach, school-based, where it incentivises the principals to reach out to the mass of students, not only a select few, is responsive as well as productive. As a result, different niches of excellence are emerging across all sectors, with teachers and school leaders at the forefront, taking ownership of innovation school-based programmes.

 

     For example, across the board, our schools now offer a broad range of curriculum offerings and opportunities to develop a global mindset to be exposed to different cultures.  This was the point that

Column: 3660

Mrs Josephine Teo made. Our Economic Strategies Committee recommended that we be a Global Asian Hub.  But if we do not expose our students to Asia, to ASEAN, let alone Asia or both, how do they have their mindset, that multi-cultural orientation? Well, Mrs Teo will be glad to know that our schools have around 200 twinning programmes with schools in South-East Asia, China and India. And in 2008 – I am using 2008 figures because H1N1 struck last year and we had to clamp down on overseas travel – 9% of primary students, 29% of secondary and one-third of JC students had a chance to go overseas; across the board, we have 500,000 students in the system.  That is no mean feat. It shows that this impact is there and it will accelerate.  And they went for school exchanges, international competitions, overseas community involvement stints. 

 

     We talked about China. 

 

 

I found out that out of 170 primary schools, 120 primary schools on their own have twinning programmes with schools in PRC.  This is a ground-up initiative, which the Ministry helps to fund.  And there are exchanges of students who come down for a week or so and that learning experience from being exposed to that is wonderful.  Many of you would have children who have gone on camps.  My own children went to an orphanage, came back, changed – different outlook, more serious sometimes, but understanding where Singapore sits, the neighbours and what learning means.
