     To stretch more academically able students, we started the Integrated Programme in 2004, only six years ago.  As you have read the recent "A" levels results, we have the first batch who graduated.  The reason was that we wanted to develop more critical, inquiring and independent learning.  We continue to monitor outcomes carefully and refine

Column: 3661

processes along the way.  It is good but not all good.  From preliminary findings, we found out, but not surprisingly, some students actually do better with the examination structure.  Some do very well without it; some not as good as they should without it.  And so we are refining the process to see how we can attain our goals.  You will remember the specialised independent schools for students with talents in Mathematics and Science, which is NUS High School, School of the Arts under MICA, and Sports School under MCYS.  They are doing well and making a mark for themselves.
 
     Since its opening in 2004, the Singapore Sports School has produced four World Champions and its students have broken 46 national open records in Track and Field and Swimming.  Students from NUS High School of Mathematics and Science, which started in 2005, have garnered 13 awards at international Olympiads over the past two years, including a Gold award for Chemistry.  For those of you who are in the know, it is very hard to get a gold at the Olympiad – you compete with the best.  The School of Arts, which started in 2008, has a beautiful campus next to Cathay.  One wonders the distractions the children have but that is another story.  It started in 2008, yet to see its first cohort graduate, but some of its students are already clinching places at summer programmes.  They gave me a list – in prestigious institutions like the English National Ballet School, the School of the Art Institute of Chicago – I visited there, it has very good programmes – as well as the Yong Siew Toh Young Artist Programme.  They have not graduated their first cohort, and yet their students have already received placements.

   

     This year, the School of Science and Technology, with its niche in applied learning and ICT learning, took in its first

Column: 3662

batch of 198 students, and is well positioned to be a new peak of excellence in the landscape, we hope.

 

      Then, on the other extreme, for those students who benefit from a different but hands-on learning style – we have Northlight School and Assumption Pathway School, which gives them a practical education.  Many of you have visited Northlight and, in future, I hope, Assumption Pathway.  If you have not, you do not need to be invited, just tell me when you can and you want to, it is an open invitation.  I think you will  be visibly moved by the passion and dedication of the principals and teachers of this group of students.

 

      I have tried to summarise what we have done over the last decade.  But the message is: the changes over the last decade or so have helped us re-shape our education system, to cater to a wide palette of students' interests and abilities, and to help every child reach his or her potential.  And the positive experiences in these selected programmes and niche schools add to the offerings of our mainstream schools and strengthen our system.  They represent the other peaks of excellence in the system.  They provide us with learning opportunities that we can start in a discrete programme because sometimes down the line it may not work so well; and at least it does not affect the general whole.  So, we will consolidate where necessary or refine and sharpen existing programmes. And where appropriate, we will also expand offerings in these selected programmes and more of such schools to benefit more students.

 

     I agree with Mr Viswa Sadasivan that principals are key to the success of schools and programmes.  Indeed, we have succeeded because there is a healthy synergy between systemic policies and ground-up initiatives.  Let me give you one example – Northlight.  When this was discussed, I remember that our

Column: 3663

approach was that the school would not start if we could not get any one to volunteer to teach in the school.  We did not want to post the people there.  Yen Ching is now the Principal.  She has more applications than places to teach in that school. To be honest, these students are difficult in a sense that they have failed the mainstream schools and many of them come with social problems, but we have no shortage of teachers.  So when I visited them, I talked to the teachers.  I asked them, "Are there social problems?" They said, "Of course, it is to be expected."  But they have evolved mechanisms to respond to these problems and they are very realistic.  They have a chart of an emergency response system any time of the day, but the chart is based on where the teacher lives and it does not matter if the particular teacher does not know the students.  To shorten the response time, you are activated so that that teacher can go to that student.  They evolved these organic responses, I call it.
 
     Mr Viswa Sadasivan suggested engaging a professional CEO for each school – thank you for the suggestion.  But I think he meant that the teachers do complain that they are overworked and they have so many administrative responsibilities, so this will free up teachers' time from "non-core" work.   We expect the principal to be the school's CEO as well as the "Chief Academic Officer" and they are trained that way.  We have the leadership track which they go on when they are vice-principals before they become principals.  But he mentioned a good idea – to get the ones with experience to help new principals.  And indeed that is what we do.  These are called the cluster superintendents.  They are experienced. They manage a group of principals and they allow them to share best practices.  So rest assured that we do recognise that the principals need leadership skills; and a principal is supported by a dedicated team of

Column: 3664

executive and administrative staff.  But let us also be clear that the principal is accountable for all aspects of school life and that includes National Education, recognising the achievements of students, setting the tone.  He is accountable; he cannot outsource his responsibility but he can get a team to help him achieve these goals.

 

     We have built a good education system but for the next decade, Members have said that we need to do more, and I agree.  I have announced that it is timely for MOE schools to put more resources to develop soft skills and values.  And this is a goal supported by as many Members that stood up to speak – all of you, Mrs Josephine Teo, Miss Penny Low, Mr Ong Kian Min and Dr Mohamad Maliki.   Mr Ong Kian Min calls it "social aptitude" – the ability to speak publicly and confidently, the ability to communicate ideas well - which is vital in the new economy.

 

     Last April, MOE accepted the recommendations of the Primary Education Review and Implementation (PERI) Committee headed by Senior Minister of State Grace Fu, which aim to nurture every child into a confident person, a self-directed learner, a concerned citizen and an active contributor.

 

     I have asked the Clerk of Parliament to distribute this to you [brochure on "Nurturing our Young for the Future – Competencies for the 21st Century " handed out ].  MOE has been thinking about this for some time.  I was struck by how much alignment and resonance between this document and what Members have said.  If Members open up the brochure, Members will see what we call "Competencies for a Changing World".  It says, simply, that we want to nurture each child to become a confident person who has a strong sense of right and wrong – I think Mrs Mildred Tan talked about this – "adaptable and resilient" – Member Joscelin Yeo mentioned this –

Column: 3665

"knows himself, is discerning in judgment, thinks independently and critically, communicates effectively, a self-directed learner who questions, reflects, perseveres and takes responsibility for his own learning" – Ms Irene Ng was very passionate about that – "an active contributor who is able to work effectively in teams, is innovative, exercises initiative, takes calculated risks and strives for excellence" – I think this is a point made by Mr Viswa Sadasivan that you are able to work with others and not only think of yourself – and "a concerned citizen who is rooted in Singapore, has a strong sense of civic responsibility, is informed about Singapore and the world, and takes an active part in bettering the lives around him". 

 

     Well, I can assure Members that the team that worked on this was not in cahoots with the MPs but Members will be struck by how much alignment there is. This was developed, in fact, by our school leaders and teachers.  We asked the professional side of the House to tell us what we want to achieve for the next lap in education.  They evolved this.  We gave very little inputs, maybe some language to make it sure that it is communicated.  They wanted this to provide a common platform for all MOE schools to anchor various efforts in developing soft skills and character.  As many Members had noted, knowledge and skills must be underpinned by values.  So they went on to develop a wheel diagram.

 

     In MOE, we have 500,000 students in many schools, so things must be communicated easily.  I am very glad that we did not spend a lot of money employing consultants.  This is done in-house.  Let me just declare that I have nothing against consultants.  But our spending will be prudent, and I think it is a very nice chart.  At the centre are Core Values.  What is it that we want to

Column: 3666

develop?  They define a person's character.  They shape his beliefs, attitudes and actions, and form the core of our approach towards nurturing 21st century competencies, rooted and grounded on values.  So, whether it is communicated in English, Mandarin, Malay or Indian, it is the same philosophy – values.  The middle ring signifies the social and emotional competencies – self-awareness, self-management, social awareness,  relationship management with others, different sexes, as well as responsible decision-making.  The outer ring represents key competencies for a globalised world – civic literacy, global awareness, cross-cultural skills, critical and inventive thinking, information and communication skills.  And then the outer aspects: four key traits in which we want to develop.

 

     I agree with Members that to do this well, a whole-school approach is required because we need every teacher or support staff to be aligned to this effort.   And they need to work with parents and other community partners – a point which Mrs Josephine Teo rightly alluded.  As the proverb goes – it takes a whole village to raise a child.

 

     Several Members – Mrs Josephine Teo, Mr Ong Kian Min and Dr Mohamad Maliki – have suggested that sports, CCAs, PE and Programme for Active Learning (PAL), in particular, are actually excellent opportunities for students to develop a range of skills.  They asked what the KPIs are, and I think what they are asking is: "Look, you teach Art, you teach PE, you teach CCA, what do you really want to achieve?"  And this is what we are trying to achieve: it is a tool, it is a platform, and through these activities you help the students acquire an awareness of their physical well-being, develop a sense of self-esteem, to pick up important values such as teamwork, fair play and a "can-do" spirit.  I think this was a point made by Ms Joscelin Yeo.

     MOE agrees wholeheartedly with all Members and will therefore provide more time, space and resources to schools for PAM (Physical education, Art and Music programmes). PE curriculum time will be increased across primary and secondary levels.  For Primary One and Primary Two, the increase will be half an hour, from 1.5 to two hours as it is now.  For Primary Three to Primary Six, it will be increased from the current 1.5 to 2.5 hours.  At the secondary level, it will be increased from one to two hours across the levels.  This will be done in phases, in step with the building of sports halls, the implementation of single-session primary schools and the recruitment of specialised teachers.

 

     I agree with Mrs Teo that sports should be for everyone, not just a select few.  And, indeed, we are working towards the mass of the students to be involved in sports competitions.  We think it is possible.  In Australia, of course, they have clubs because they are geographically segregated.  We do not really need that.  I think it is very hard to start it, but we think it is actually possible for MOE to run competitions at various levels, whether it is at the novice level, intermediate or advance level, so that competitions are for the masses.  I think Mdm Cynthia Phua brought this up before and we have been working on it.

     Now, I completely agree, too, about specialisation of teachers.  I think some Members brought up the point.  To enhance the delivery of the Art and Music curriculum, MOE has decided that all new Art and Music teachers will be trained for single-subject specialisation, ie, just one subject. 

 

 

In short, they will focus on teaching either Music or Art, and handle Art- or Music-related CCAs and programmes. Existing Art and Music teachers will also move towards single-subject specialisation.  PE teachers are currently

Column: 3668

trained to teach a second subject, but are deployed mainly to teach PE. That is because some PE teachers do like this ability to be cross-deployed in subjects beyond PE which provides them with the flexibility to switch to other subjects when they lose their flexibility.  MOE proposes to allow more flexibility in the training and deployment of PE teachers.  In other words, it means that teachers who prefer to teach only PE and sports-related work can already do so, if this suits the needs of the schools.  We will step up the recruitment of PE teachers in tandem with the building of infrastructure in our schools as we allow more PE curriculum time.

 

   This is going to have a large impact on our recruitment.  In view of single-subject specialisation, more PE, Art and Music teachers will obviously be needed and will be recruited. We currently have 2,500 qualified PE, Art and Music (PAM) teachers. We have to build up the pipeline of PE, Art and Music teachers by 2020. And we have done our calculations. We will need 80% more, nearly doubled, four-fifths more, to be mathematically precise.  Otherwise, my students would say that I do not know my Mathematics.

 

     This move will provide an attractive career option for PAM teachers and enable them to elevate the standards of these programmes in schools to achieve our educational outcomes. We are serious about this. We want them to stay within the system.  We are providing the same three career tracks that are given to academic teachers.  In other words, if they teach PE, Art and Music, they can aspire to be principals or be in positions of school leadership while those who are interested in advancing by doing research and developments can go that track and be Senior Specialists in MOE HQ.  Those who are interested to become "teachers of teachers", ie, Master Teachers, can also do that.  I have already announced that we are starting two institutions to

Column: 3669

support this – the Physical Education and Sports Teacher Academy (PESTA) and the Singapore Teachers' Academy for the aRts (STAR). This is a professional home to ground to help them develop professionally.

 

     Mr Ong Kian Min asked about the KPIs for PAM programmes and Mrs Teo suggested introducing new categories in Edusave Merit Bursary awards to recognise achievements in sports, art and music.  And she gave me a discreet number – 1,000. Our schools have clear expectations and learning outcomes for these domains. Last year, we gave close to 7,500 awards. In short, this award already exists.  It is called the EAGLES award.  It is an Edusave award for Achievement, Good Learning and Service. I understand that they want it more discreet and I will look into that.  It may be a good idea.  But we have given this and it amounted to about $1.3 million to recognise students for their achievements in sports, art and music.

 

     Let me move on to communication skills and language ability.  I agree with Mr Ong Kian Min that the ability to communicate with clarity, impact and emotional appeal is a valuable asset. English is paramount because it is the lingua franca of the globalised world and Internet.  And we agree that teachers are role models for the use of good English.  We have strengthened in-service training.  I need to be honest, we have a long way to go in terms of raising English standards.  We are starting, we are consolidating. We need to pool much needed expertise and training resources in teaching English to bilingual learners. And as I have announced, the English Language Institute of Singapore (ELIS) will be set up. Senior Minister of State Iswaran will give further details.

 

     Mr Ong Kian Min suggested encouraging more students to learn Malay as a

third language. MOE agrees. So far, the response from students has been positive.  Let me give you some figures. Around 500 Secondary 1 students offer Malay as a third language, while 80 offer Bahasa Indonesia. It is a small proportion of a large base, but at least it is a start.  Of these, 130 students are enrolled in the regional studies programme, which MOE started in 2008.

 

     Mr Baey Yam Keng, Mrs Josephine Teo, Mr Low Thia Khiang and Mr Teo Siong Seng spoke about the teaching of Chinese language. With the rise of China, we absolutely agree that it will be a valuable cachet.  Similarly for those who speak Malay or Tamil languages as markets in Indonesia, Malaysia and India expand.

 

     There has been considerable debate over the last few months and I need not repeat the arguments today. As announced, the Director-General of Education is currently leading a review of three Mother Tongue Languages (MTLs), to respond to the language home environments and educational goals.  Mrs Teo suggested that this should be grounded on solid educational grounds and not personal experience.  She is right. That is the way to move forward.  The review is expected to be completed by year end.  It will design a mother tongue curriculum structure that basically recognises the wider range of starting points.  It recognises the starting points of students' home environment, their prior backgrounds and devise customised approaches for different groups of learners.

 

      The basic goal is the same. There is alignment here.  We want to evolve a framework that will facilitate the learning of Mother Tongue Languages in three broad groups – the majority who come from English language-speaking homes, those who are are very capable and the

Column: 3671

other extreme, those who face exceptional difficulties.

 

     For those with the ability and interest to do higher mother tongue, we agree to help them to develop fluency in all these programmes. There are good avenues to do this, such as SAP schools and the Bicultural Studies Programme (Chinese) (BSP(C)), and the Higher Malay and Higher Tamil programmes. As I have said, if there is demand for more SAP schools, MOE will build them.

 

     For the vast majority, the middle ground, the goal is the same.  We do want our students to cultivate an interest to be able to use the language because if they do not use it, they will lose it, and we want our teaching methods to encourage students to use the language. This is the point that Mr Baey Yam Keng made so strongly. We need to engage him because he is very hip and he is able to connect, whether it is the films that he suggested or the pop songs.  I think that there is traction. Kids will be excited about this.  So, Mr Baey, if you do receive a call, you will know why.  For those who face difficulties in learning the language, we want them to acquire competency in oral communications for daily living.

 

     Apart from teaching – Members are again right – how we test students will shape their attitudes towards the language. Mrs Teo said, "Look, grounded on educational grounds."  We are.  We are open-minded and indeed, we are studying various systems, from China, Cambridge and advanced placements in the United States. This is work-in-progress but let me give you one example.  China's Hanyu Shuiping Kaoshi (HSK) is a proficiency test geared towards learners, not as a foreign language, but who are not immersed in the Chinese language environment.  They are not immersed. They can hear it sometimes but it is not the total immersion.  They adopt the philosophy of encouraging and motivating

Column: 3672

more students. They treat language proficiency as a marathon, not as a sprint, encouraging each student to finish but at his own pace without being discouraged between him and the other person who finished first before him is very wide.  And I think that is an enlightened approach.  Consistent with this approach, HSK has multiple proficiency levels.  If you imagine someone coming at Primary 1 who comes from an English language background versus one who comes from and is immersed in a Chinese language-speaking background, they have different starting points. The catch-up speed, even by Primary 6, may be very different.

 

     The HSK philosophy is that, "You may not be able to catch up but even if that gap is still wide, I want to encourage you to go even higher at the next level – secondary school, pre-U and even university".  It is an entirely different approach. They make the language accessible with great emphasis on listening/speaking skills but less on writing for the beginning levels.  Because they believe if we help them to listen and speak, for those when they gain their proficiency, they then move on to writing.  The test questions that they start with at the beginning level are contextualised. They use exactly what Mr Baey Yam Keng said, "What do you do in a social situation? How do you respond?  How do you respond not in a stilted way but in a conversational way?"  They start with very reachable goals – a vocabulary book with 581 characters which forms 90% of all daily conversations.  Five hundred and eighty-one is achievable, right?  It is quite different from 3,000 characters. If they study that, 90% of the time, you can communicate with somebody.  This goes a long way towards motivating the learner with a sense of achievement to acquire enough proficiency to function in several scenarios.

 

     I agree with Mrs Teo that we do not have to swing to a position where mother
